After speaking, the king said:

At that time, all the heavenly beings there gathered together, and the king of the YÄma Heaven spoke a verse, saying:
The various realms in the world, various karmas are sovereign,
The various paths of the heavens lead here, good karma gives birth to this place.
Some come like this, some leave like this,
Just as karma leads one to come, so it leads one to go.
All things that come together, all intentions are not confused,
All are created by good karma, be diligent and do not be negligent.
For a long time you will experience pleasure, but after this you will certainly fall,
Falling is the greatest suffering, there is no doubt that you will be reborn.
This meaning I call you to explain,

The king of the Heaven of YÄma, having thus universally benefited and spoken this verse to all the gods, said to the assembly of gods:
You delight in engaging in sense objects and are deluded, yet you do not realize that the gods are then diminished and do not flourish.
These pleasures of sense objects are all impermanent, will not be tranquil, and will bring harm.
What is it that is said?
Listen all!
As you see, the six who have attained right knowledge, the seven-jeweled stÅ«pas adorned and perfected with various seven treasures,

At that time, the gods first respectfully and single-mindedly contemplated, all silent and still, with two kinds of respect:

It is said that if gods or humans are destroyed by negligence, they will not be able to do good, whether worldly good or supramundane good.
As for worldly dharmas, if the mind is lazy or negligent, practicing negligent conduct, then all worldly dharmas will be destroyed.
If one is negligent, one will not be able to look up to good friends, and will then become an ordinary person;
If they are enemies, the enemies will increase and seek opportunities.
This is the hindrance of negligence to worldly affairs;
Those who are lazy and negligent cannot accomplish such deeds.

When their karma is exhausted, even their friends will be exhausted, and their enemies will grow stronger and more powerful. Their families will all be lost, they will be poor and have nothing, and will be despised by others.
The most contemptible are called the poor.
For those poor and contemptible men, greed, anger, and wrong views increase towards good friends, acquaintances, relatives, and siblings.

Thus, those who engage in heedless and indulgent conduct are always impure in mind, greedy for the taste of food like animals that eat vomit, their minds like dogs, also like those who observe the precepts of a crow-dog.

Such people always engage in heedless and indulgent conduct, do not recite sÅ«tras, and among their retinue and those of much learning, they are of little wisdom and are vulgar, despised by donors, and devoid of fearlessness.

toward those with much learning, those who truly know, toward elders, and toward those with good roots who are benefactors, due to their foolishness and much negligence, they give rise to the sores of an angry mind.
Due to unwholesome actions, when their body breaks up and their life ends, they fall into a bad realm of existence and are born in hell.
Those who practice negligence in this way, due to practicing negligence among humans, create obstacles to worldly and transcendent meaning.
Monks!
How do the gods in the heavens destroy themselves through negligence?

Those who practice negligence by nature, the gods who practice negligence, with their minds delighting in the tastes of touch, form, smell, and so forth, practice negligence, do not see old age coming, do not see destruction, do not see decline, do not contemplate the exhaustion and cessation of good karma, do not practice the Dharma, and do not respect the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha.
They are separated from wholesome thoughts, engage in negligence, do not see or know the Buddha when he appears in the world, and do not give rise to faith in their minds.
Fear is near, misfortune is near, the suffering of death is near, the suffering of separation is near, and the celestial maidens abandon them.

Great fear is near, like one who falls from a steep cliff. They do not fully see the pleasurable things they have experienced in the past, and do not follow the right path in other lives. At the time of death, they are not given happiness or comforted.
Such objects are all destroyed, without any power. When going to other realms in existence, they do not accompany each other.
If one acts negligently, the karma of negligent conduct will follow one in existence.
Thirsty for objects, the mind is not yet satisfied, and one dies negligently.

All the gods abandon it, their minds become frightened, and they are confused by the objects. In this way, they die. At that time, they may be reborn in the three evil destinies of hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
Therefore, gods and humans should not indulge in carelessness.
' At that time, Shiqi Tathagata spoke a verse, saying:
If the gods always attain the pleasures of the objects,
When those gods are destroyed, their karma follows them.
Pleasure cannot be permanently retained, and accumulated karma is not lost.
The deluded gods are deceived by pleasure, and due to karma, they are not free.
The objects appear to bring pleasure, but later they can cause harm.
The gods who are attached to the objects, their minds are always disturbed and unstable.
They do not know the wholesome and meritorious karma, which is the medicine for the illness of birth and death.
Like medicine and lamps, they are the refuge and the savior.
The good karma in the intermediate state follows sentient beings,
Therefore, the wise should always diligently make effort.
Cultivating merit and virtue is auspicious, abandoning sense objects is good,
If there is the eye of wisdom, one knows to fear the future.
The wise preemptively give rise to fear, the foolish fear when the time arrives,
The wise know this, their minds always concerned about destruction.
If the mind is always foolish, then one delights in sense objects,
Confused by sense objects, later the mind gives rise to regret.
Those whose bodies are harmonious and whose wisdom is always untainted,
All create meritorious deeds, without merit there is suffering.

Thus, the YÄma Heaven King Moxiu Loutuo first showed the heavenly beings the verses spoken by the TathÄgata Åšikhin written on the wall, and then subsequently showed them the other seven dharmas, saying:
I will further explain the remaining seven dharmas for you.
Next is arrogance, which is always unchecked.
Those who act arrogantly are always unchecked. They always obstruct the dharmas of the world and the dharmas beyond the world.
How do they obstruct the meanings of the world and the meanings beyond the world?
Those who are arrogant in body disturb their mind and intention.
The meaning of all dharmas is led by the mind and intention, and therefore it turns and moves.
That disturbed mind and intention goes to unwholesome places, inappropriate places, and goes at inappropriate times, to dangerous places, and associates with bad friends.
They do not measure themselves and do not know others, do not know their own strength, and do not know the strength of others.
Because of arrogance, they are unable to work and do not know how to manage their own affairs, like a madman.
They do not engage in proper conduct and are the most vulgar among all people. They are also the most inferior among their relatives, brothers, and so forth.
They do what should not be done and are unable to do what should be done.
They do not know what should be done and what should not be done, and they also do not know what is done and what is not done.

They are also unable to know what is Dharma and what is not Dharma, and they do not know what should be said and what should not be said, what should be practiced and what should not be practiced, and they also do not know what is appropriate and what is not appropriate.
In this way, they do not know anything at all.
Because of arrogance, they are unable to know the Dharma of upholding precepts.
Also, because of arrogance, they do not know the proper time, place, state of mind, or lack thereof.
Because of arrogance, they do not know when to enjoy themselves, do not know light and heavy, do not know true and false, and walk around with a haughty face, without any fear or restraint.
'Moreover, this arrogance obstructs the meaning of the supramundane Dharma. How does it obstruct the meaning of the supramundane?

Those obstructed and disturbed by this arrogance do not know the causes of karma, do not know the fruits of retribution, do not know the good and bad paths, do not know proper conduct, do not know directions and places, do not know time and season, do not know how much is enough or not enough, and do not know the great assembly.
Even if they hear the Dharma, they cannot practice it;
they have no desire to hear the unheard Dharma and have no intention to inquire.

They are fierce and stubborn, fearless, and their words are not in accordance with reason. Their minds are agitated and scattered like dust moved by the wind. Their minds are always like this, unsettled.
Those whose minds are confused and arrogant do not cultivate meditation and concentration, and cannot control their minds. When they see forms, they become attached and delight in objects.

Sometimes they become lustful, and their eyes are always moving. Such restless people, because of their improper eyes, act arrogantly, either due to attachment to desire, or intoxication and confusion, or sometimes due to misfortune or madness, always like this, no different.
Because of this, they are pointed out by the world.
Because of being pointed out like this, they are despised by everyone, not knowing their own faults.
This is not beneficial, not helpful, and not peaceful and happy. They do not accomplish anything meaningful.
'How does arrogance obstruct the worldly and supramundane Dharma-Vinaya?
How does it also obstruct those who are arrogant?
It means that among humans, the conduct of arrogant renunciants is the most contemptible.
This Dharma and Vinaya can eliminate arrogance and all that is dignified;
Those who do not eliminate arrogance are not dignified.

Arrogant people cannot cultivate meditation, do not know how to abide, always go to cities, towns, and villages, do not go to good places, cannot speak the Dharma to subdue patrons, only crave food, drink, bedding, and bedding, and only do not observe well.
Such people, when their bodies perish and their lives end, fall into evil paths, are born in hells, hungry ghosts, and animal realms.
Such people are not at ease in either the worldly path or the supramundane path.
There are seven kinds of arrogance:
First, arrogance of appearance;
Second, arrogance of wealth;
Third, arrogance of birth;
Fourth, arrogance of clothing and adornments, etc.;
Fifth, arrogance due to being honored by the king;ğŸ”½Sixth, arrogance due to being close to women;
Seventh, arrogance due to lustful thoughts about others' wives.
This is generally called pride, whether in abbreviated form, incomplete form, or complete form.
This pride obstructs all dharmas.
In the human realm, there is little wealth and pleasure, and life is short. Even with such a short life, one is still arrogant. How much more so in the heavens? This is pride.
The gods love sound, touch, taste, smell, and form, and their arrogance increases moment by moment.

Because of arrogant conduct, their lives gradually decrease. They are unaware of the passing of life, do not know when their lives will end, do not know when their actions will end, and do not know whether their actions are good or bad.
At all times, they are always like this until their lives end, and their arrogance does not cease.
In sequence, until their good and beloved karma is exhausted, when the karma is exhausted they will fall back. When they are about to fall back, they will then realize and give rise to this thought:

In this way, pride deceives them. When their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil paths and are born in the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.
In this way, arrogance obstructs the worldly path.
Moreover, due to arrogance, the celestial beings obstruct the supramundane path.

However, due to arrogant conduct, they do not know their own karma. They do not associate with those who practice less arrogance, nor do they associate with those who practice non-arrogance. Due to not following the right Dharma, they proceed along the evil path.

They are deceived by desire and crave for sense objects.
When they are about to fall from this celestial realm, they give rise to regret.
Therefore, celestial beings should abandon heedlessness and should relinquish arrogance.
If they do not abandon it, it will be like a blazing fire burning sesame seeds, etc.
The Tathagata Shiji then spoke a verse, saying:

Whether gods or humans, they do not attain the bliss of tranquility.
If one delights in negligent conduct, that is called death;
The faults of negligent pleasures lead to falling into hell.
The fault of practicing the wrong path is called negligence;
Negligence deceives the minds of the gods, and they enter hell.
Delighting in the unreal, not delighting in the real,
Because of the darkness of the defilement of negligence, the gods are deceived by desire.
The gods deluded by desire, negligent and arrogant,
Are unable to truly see, like the congenitally blind on the path.
The Blessed One Shiqi said that a mind of negligence and arrogance obstructs both worldly and transcendent dharmas, and further, that the third is the fault of breaking precepts.

At that time, King of the Heaven Moshoulou showed the heavenly beings the written words on the wall of the stupa about the faults of not upholding precepts:

What is it?
Because of not upholding precepts among humans, it obstructs the worldly path.
That is to say, a foolish person who receives precepts does not know what to do or not to do after receiving precepts. He also does not know what is appropriate or inappropriate.
Having committed offenses, they conceal them in their hearts.

For the sake of brothers and relatives, they break the precepts like this, exclusively for the sake of brothers and relatives, not caring about the precepts or not taking up the precepts, and after receiving them, they violate them, not feeling any difficulty.
For this reason, they are all despised by relatives, brothers, and all people, who say:
This one does not uphold the precepts, is not diligent in effort, and does not uphold the precepts of body, speech, and mind.
Relatives and even brothers despise and look down upon him like this.
Because of being despised, they do not care about auspicious or inauspicious times, and do not associate with him.

At auspicious or inauspicious gatherings, they do not invite or summon him, do not believe in him, and do not respect him, because such a person does not accept the precepts, does not uphold the precepts, and does not gather the precepts.
Those who were originally good friends become neutral;
if there were previous enemies, they seek out his weaknesses;
If they are neither enemies nor friends, they will not be included as companions.
Such a person is like a tree with severed roots, blown down by the wind, fallen to the ground, losing all possessions, and separated from all relatives.

The nature of such a person's mind is fickle. Because of fickleness, they harbor evil within, are greedy and angry towards all people, have a suspicious and doubtful mind, and wish to cause trouble through discrimination and hope. Their mind always hates all beings, their facial expression is unpleasant, they have no dignity, their mind is unstable, and they are always poor.
Because such a person does not accept precepts and does not uphold precepts, when their body perishes and their life ends, they fall into a bad realm and are born in hell.
Therefore, one should always remember to benefit, accept precepts, and uphold precepts, without interfering with worldly dharmas.
The one who upholds precepts, due to the causes and conditions of precepts, has a firm mind, always correctly recollects, and has faith in good friends.

If the king or ministers have faith in that person, they will entrust them with valuable gold, silver, and various treasures. If they confide secrets, they will believe and tell them. If the king or others entrust them with things, they will not take advantage of them, and secrets will not be revealed.
Because they uphold the precepts, they are trusted by others.

Moreover, all relatives, brothers, and family members, and all people at all times, trust, love, and make offerings to them. They are respected even more than elders. Upholding the seven kinds of precepts, the king also makes offerings to them. Acquaintances and relatives all make offerings to them.
Such a person is trusted by all people and loved by all people. They are always wealthy and never poor. No one can harm them. They are the richest of the rich.
Because they are very wealthy, they are able to practice giving and create blessings and virtues. They abide in the right mind with indestructible wisdom.
For these reasons, when their body perishes and their life ends, they are reborn in the heavens, the realm of good destinations.
That person, with such slight broken precepts, is already inferior, let alone practicing the supramundane path.
Such a person's mind is restless and does not abide in the fruits of karma, blind and lacking the eye of wisdom.
Either not upholding precepts or breaking many precepts, only one precept remains or none at all, others call them bhiká¹£us:
That person only has the appearance and attire of a bhiká¹£u, like the sound of a conch shell.
The mind is always deceitful, deceiving donors, saying such things:
I uphold the Buddha's precepts.
Such a person truly does not uphold the precepts, and does not truly accomplish the precepts loved by the sages.
He is a deceitful thief, deceiving the world, devas, MÄra, all Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, devas, humans, and so forth. He deceives both himself and others, and does not practice as he speaks.
Such a person is internally empty and without substance, unreal and unstable, like a mass of foam, deceiving all people, the most deceitful.
That person seeks many bedding and medical supplies, taking much from everywhere.
That person is always sinking in the mud of birth and death, or is born in the hells or other evil destinies.
That person breaks the precepts and takes what should not be taken. Because of breaking the precepts, they are included in the unwholesome category.
Such a person should not even walk one step on the ground of the Sangha, because it is inappropriate and not proper.
What is the reason for this?
Because the donors cultivate that ground for the sake of the monks who uphold the precepts, not for those who have no precepts or break the precepts, not for anyone who lacks a wholesome mind.
Such a person should not even take a single step on that ground, let alone use bedding, medicine, or other necessities.
At that time, Shiqi Tathagata spoke a verse, saying:
If a bhikshu has no precepts, he is a thief among thieves;
Inside filled with rotten pus and other impurities, outside wearing a kasaya robe.
All is empty and insubstantial, like a mass of foam;
Thus empty and without precepts, falsely claiming to be a bhikshu.
Breaking the precepts belongs to hell, not included in the Sangha's treasures;
Deceived by the mind, the body perishes and falls into hell.
Far from the Dharma and Vinaya, falling due to one's own karma;
Covered by defilement and darkness, always experiencing great suffering.
Not wearing the robe of wholesome dharmas, naked and abandoned by good people;
Because of abandoning wholesome actions, evil will lead to hell.
Accumulating unwholesome actions, the door to suffering opens wide,
The bonds of birth and death are firm, because of breaking precepts, it is like this.
Burned by the fire of breaking precepts, they will be burned to the extreme;
Thus, those who lack precepts will definitely enter the evil paths.
Because the mind receives and upholds precepts, the teacher can bestow precepts;
Without a sincere mind, hypocritically receiving precepts, one will definitely enter hell.
For that person, day and night, unwholesomeness always increases and grows,
If one can uphold the precious precepts, then one can destroy breaking precepts.
If a person is empty and has no Dharma, only darkness accumulates,
For him, there is not a single moment when he is not destroyed.ğŸ”½Because of the defilement of being bound by breaking precepts, good people abandon him,
The snare of breaking precepts always drags along those who abandon precepts and do unwholesome things.
Those without precepts or who violate precepts, who associate with bad friends,
Or those who indulge in desires, these are causes for hell.
Those without precepts or foolish people, or those who are restless,
Or those who are associated with evil karma, are not far from hell.
Karma has similar fruits, why do you not know this?
Out of delusion, you create your own suffering, yet you are attached to the pleasures of play.
Day after day it increases, the evil river cannot be crossed,
The waves of suffering fill it, thus it carries away sentient beings.
That person is not creating good, that person does not have a good mind;
If one abandons the Dharma, then unwholesome dharmas are included.
If the body includes wholesome dharmas, this is the foremost good path;
The person who practices those phrases will reach the stage of non-retrogression.
Those who uphold precepts and read sutras, who delight in wholesome dharmas,
Always well-disciplined in right practice, they are free from suffering and distress.
This impurity of not upholding precepts can defile,
Because it destroys learning, it is included in hell.
Knowing this, one should diligently uphold precepts with a focused mind,
For in the ocean of all birth and death, lack of precepts is the cause.
Thus it is said that for all people, the supramundane path is obstructed by lack of precepts.
How does lack of precepts obstruct the heavenly realm?

In this world, the ground of karmic results, if one upholds the seven kinds of precepts, gathers and accumulates them, one will experience heavenly bliss. Having indulged for a long time, until the bliss is exhausted, one will then fall.
Just as when the oil is exhausted and the wick is exhausted, the light is also extinguished.
How does lack of precepts obstruct the supramundane path?
Those who observe precepts are reborn among the gods. Having been born there, they think like this:
I observed the seven kinds of precepts among humans and was reborn here, equal to the gods.
Because this newly born god is attached to the pleasures of desire and objects, he forgets everything.
If the other gods do not forget observing precepts, they will show this god the fruits of observing precepts and tell him:
You observed precepts fully among humans and were reborn here.

Because the newly born god's mind is agitated, attached to the pleasures of objects, he does not hear the words, does not enter or grasp them, and does not believe in observing precepts. Therefore, he cannot grasp the fruits of good karma.
Because the power of objects agitates his mind, he does not observe precepts or follow the practice of the Dharma.
In this way, the gods destroy good dharmas and therefore fall back.
In this way, observing precepts leads to rebirth among the gods, either in the mundane or supramundane realms.
In the world, because of upholding precepts, this is one kind.
In the supramundane, it is bodhi.
This third Dharma obstructs not upholding precepts.
What is the fourth, the obstruction of devas and humans?
It is called laziness.
A person who delights in laziness and is attached, such a person does not accomplish any Dharma in any way in the entire world.
That lazy person is inferior in seven ways.
What are the seven?
If a person is lazy, lacking in superior fruits, this is the first inferiority.
Because of this inferiority, offerings are inferior, wealth and riches are inferior, and the wisdom of objects is inferior.
Because of this inferiority, the true men of the world do not associate with them, and when worldly people inquire about their greetings, they are inferior.
That person is inferior in all worldly matters in this way, and therefore they are dull and all their undertakings are ruined.
In the human realm, worldly matters are hindered by laziness.
How does laziness hinder supramundane dharmas in the human realm?
It is because of laziness.
This lazy person fears all household affairs and work, so they go forth and say:
After I go forth, I will have plenty of bedding and medicine, and abundant food and drink.
I will have nothing to do day or night.
Because of their laziness, they go forth like this.
Having gone forth, they do not recite sutras, cannot stop evil, do not practice good dharmas, do not cultivate meditation, and do not uphold precepts, always covered by laziness.
That person gains much profit, receives abundant offerings and food, but does not enjoy upholding precepts or wisdom.
Because of the fault of little wisdom, when their body perishes and life ends, they fall into a bad realm and are born in hell.
The Tathagata Shiji then spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½Lazy, with little merit and virtue,
Foolishness can destroy the mind,
All relatives are thin, and the good path cannot be obtained.
Laziness and evil karma, or being covered by foolishness,
Obstruct the path to nirvana, and obtain unwholesome evil fruits.
Without shame or conscience, agitated and with evil friends,
All are causes of suffering and distress, which the wise abandon.
Evil, arrogance, great arrogance, such as this self-arrogance and so forth,
Always abandon all of these, and accept the causes and conditions of suffering and distress.
If covered by laziness, not remembering to give rise to activity,
Exhaling is the same as death, empty life without fruit.ğŸ”½Those who suffer from laziness,
Even with life, are the same as dead,ğŸ”½Such a lazy person,
Thinking of death as supreme.
If one is mired in the mud of laziness, one will sink in the ocean of suffering and not emerge.
If a person diligently practices, they will cross the ocean of birth and death.
A person with little strength and laziness is like a sheep that loves food and drink.
Even if their life is not yet over, they are like a dead person, and if they die, they will enter hell.
The poor and foolish are like sheep, and may be bound by suffering.
If a person eats the food of others, laziness is the cause.
If there are those who are lazy, they often depend on others for their livelihood.
They crave delicious flavors, and their minds are always deluded and lustful.
They do not know the truth, but only crave the taste of food.
When death arrives, the fire of regret burns their minds.
Those who endure cold and heat, and even hunger and thirst,
Suffer physical pain in this way, but later attain peace and tranquility.
Do not give rise to lazy thoughts, for laziness leads to weakness.
Unable to endure birth and death, they cannot escape suffering and distress.
Lazy ones are empty in the world, ordinary among the virtuous,
And in the future they will also be empty, never attaining tranquility.
The lazy person, apart from these faults, has another fault, namely, being far from the supramundane path.
The lazy person is an unvirtuous person, a person who falls back.
How do the gods lose the worldly and supramundane legal code and discipline?
How do the gods obstruct the worldly path?
Namely, this laziness has another effect. If due to wholesome causes, they are born among the gods.

Those gods are again destroyed by laziness. All beloved sounds, touches, tastes, smells, and forms, the mind no longer delights in them. They do not delight in the gardens, forests, and delightful places of the gods. They do not fly or run, do not listen to singing, and do not sing themselves.
They do not fly in the sky, do not go from one mountain peak to another, are not in the river, and do not cross the waves, riding on birds and playing.
In this way, the king of the Heaven of YÄma has such pleasures, but those lazy gods do not go to him, and they do not experience any of the pleasures of the king of the Heaven of YÄma's realm.
All of it is like poison, like an enemy, and is all defilement.
This is the laziness that obstructs the world.
'How does laziness also obstruct the path to transcendence?
If other gods always hear the true Dharma and delight in the true Dharma, they are unable to approach it.

Far from the true Dharma, they have no desire to hear the Dharma they have not heard, and even if they hear it, they do not uphold it, nor do they practice it, nor do they approach the elders, nor do they learn wisdom, they are apart from all dharmas, apart from all good, always delighting in saá¹ƒsÄra, always experiencing suffering.
Why is this?
Because they are separated from the path, they cannot attain liberation within existence.
They are destroyed by laziness and are born in the hells, hungry ghost realm, or animal realm.
They are always bound by birth, old age, death, and so forth, and experience various sufferings as they transmigrate in the world.
Laziness is like this laziness, which is all that is unbeneficial, and is also the root of all evil paths and the seed of birth and death. Therefore, all the sufferings of the world arise from this.
Therefore, if there are those in the world who wish to be liberated from the bonds of birth and death, they should diligently abandon laziness.
All that is unbeneficial has this as its root. Such laziness is unable to cross the ocean of suffering.
This laziness has immeasurable faults.
Furthermore, having eliminated these four faults, there is a fifth fault that obstructs the worldly and supramundane paths for gods and humans, namely, evil greed.
All worldly and supramundane dharmas are universally obstructed.
How do gods and humans obstruct the worldly and supramundane paths through evil greed?
Namely, laypeople, due to greedy minds, engage in unwholesome conduct, always delighting in wealth and objects. Their love for objects is like a whirlpool in a river or a monkey.
Because the mind loves objects and desires to obtain them, they devise various means. In this way, evil greed grows.
They think like this:
What means and deceptions should I employ to deceive others?
The mind is always like this, deceiving and tricking, and they also teach others to deceive and trick in this way.
Such a person often engages in non-dharma and teaches others to do the same.
Such a person has a greedy mind and thinks like this:
All the possessions of others belong to me.
Having thought like this, he teaches others.
Having taught others, he then follows them to deceive and trick others, using various means to deceive and trick others and take their possessions.
Having deceived like this, he is delighted and thinks like this:
I am good at this!
I can deceive and trick others and take their possessions.
Originally they belonged to others, but now they belong to me.
He gives rise to such thoughts, and therefore is delighted. He obtains their essence and flavor, and in this way he delights in engaging in and creating much suffering for others.
With evil greed covering their minds, they destroy cities, towns, villages, and inhabited places, or burn cities, towns, villages, and inhabited places.
They are abandoned by all people and despised by all good people.
They are the great thorns of all countries, the thorns of cities, and the thorns of villages.
They destroy countries, destroy cities, destroy villages, destroy houses, destroy other clans, and always delight in such evil to bring harm to others.
Such evil people, when their bodies perish and their lives end, fall into evil paths and are born in hells.
In this world, those with evil greed are people with evil greed who obstruct the world.
Evil greed, having accumulated, further increases and grows, like fire getting fuel.
In this way, evil greed grows, and in this way, evil greed becomes skillful. In this way, one obtains the wealth of others, and in this way, it grows even more.
Therefore, those who practice merit diligently abandon evil greed.
Why is this?
The first defilement is called the greedy mind that takes the wealth of others.
Those who are defiled by this enter hell.
At that time, Shiqi Tathagata spoke a verse, saying:
If a person engages in deception and deceitfully takes the wealth of others,
Then this is a greatly greedy mind, always engaging in unwholesome conduct.
For that person, day and night, the mind is always impure,
Because greed covers the mind, always hoping for the wealth of others.
That person is like the fire at the end of an eon, with a nature that is inherently evil,
Feared by all, like a poisonous snake.
If a person commits evil for the sake of greed, always covering their mind,
They will constantly enter the hells and the realms of hungry ghosts and so forth.
In the great hells, having escaped the hot places,
If reborn as a human, for five hundred lifetimes they will be poor.
Their face will be ruined and their mouth wrinkled, always experiencing suffering and distress,
For those whose minds are ruined by greed, they will all experience suffering like this.
If a person abandons greed and always aspires for wisdom,
They will always have the power of spiritual penetrations and will practice the good path.
Removing greed from the mind is like closing a snake's den.
If bitten by a greedy snake, one will definitely experience suffering and distress.
For those with greedy minds, their thoughts increase moment by moment,
Like a fire getting dry firewood, it blazes and grows.
People who delight in wealth and possessions always aspire for things,
When death arrives, all possessions are left behind.
If one has done evil, it will not be lost in the end,
That person, bound by greed, will be led into hell.
Wealth belongs to others, and one's own evil karma defiles,
Seeing what is not wealth as wealth, considering what is not happiness as happiness.
Evil greed dwells in the mind, seeing enemies as good friends,
The fire of greed can burn people, the wise do not accumulate greed.
A person burned by greed will later enter hell,
Wealth in the world is like a mountain, all is impermanent.
Why, for the sake of wealth, do such evil deeds?
Only the foolish are able to do such evil.
Do not do such evil greed yourself, do not let others do it.
Such evil greed obstructs the world.
The accumulation of evil greed increases day by day, like fire getting fuel, thus it blazes and grows.
In this way, evil greed grows due to obtaining wealth, and it grows and becomes rampant together with stinginess and jealousy. Therefore, all virtuous people should abandon it.
You heavenly beings should know this:

There are merchants who buy food and drink or other things at a low price, and if they hold a feast and make offerings to Å›ramaá¹‡as or brÄhmaá¹‡as, it is to make others know that they are virtuous people who can be trusted;

Although they make offerings, it is not with a pure mind, but to make others believe in them. They do business seeking profit, buying at a low price and selling at a high price.
Using such methods, they make offerings with little and obtain much more, perhaps ten times or eight times as much.
Such evil greed is abandoned by virtuous people.
The second is abandoning evil greed.

Evil greed refers to Dharma masters who expound the Dharma and accept offerings, but use the obtained objects for personal purposes rather than for the Three Jewels. This is evil greed and should be abandoned.
The third is abandoning evil greed.
Evil greed refers to renunciant people who sell Buddha images made of white elephant tusks, embroidered images, Buddha images painted on silk, carved wooden images, or bronze images.
After obtaining the objects, they use them inappropriately.
Among humans, there is such evil greed that obstructs worldly and transcendent dharmas. The wise criticize and abandon it.
What is called evil greed among the gods?
Even though you gods have such great joy, you still have evil greed.

In this way, you will see the golden mountains, the beryl mountains, the blue sapphire mountains, the great blue sapphire mountains, and the crystal mountains, one by one, playing and enjoying yourselves. Having enjoyed yourselves on one mountain, you will go to another mountain to enjoy yourselves with the heavenly maidens in various ways, surrounded by the heavenly multitudes.
In this way, everything is due to greed, not created by anything else.

You heavenly multitudes are bound by love and greed, falling into evil paths without realizing it, without fear, not afraid of the suffering of death, not afraid of the separation of beloved relatives and so forth.
Not realizing the various sufferings of decline.
You heavenly multitudes, because of greedy minds, are fearless and unaware.
You heavenly multitudes, such greedy minds are immeasurable and boundless. The work of Mara, the greedy mind, is insatiable, not afraid of separation, not afraid of the suffering of death.
Such evil greed obstructs the worldly path.
What is the heavenly mind of greed that obstructs the supramundane path?
This love for sound, touch, taste, form, and smell brings about the pleasure of happiness.

The gods with greedy minds do not go to the other gods with little greed to listen to the Dharma, hear the Dharma, seek the Dharma, or study the Dharma. They do not wish to hear the Dharma to purify their minds.
The supreme root of all good dharmas is called the realization of the Dharma.
The realization of all dharmas must come from hearing the Dharma. If one does not hear the Dharma, one will not realize the Dharma.
Why is it not realized?
Because of negligence.
Moreover, what is the root of negligence?
It is called the greedy mind.
Therefore, one should abandon the greedy mind. If one abandons the greedy mind, one will reach nirvana.
Those covered by greed revolve in birth and death.
The heavenly multitudes should know!
The supramundane path is obstructed by evil greed among gods and humans. Therefore, the wise should always diligently abandon evil greed.
There are three kinds of giving:
First, giving of material things;
Second, giving of fearlessness;
Third, giving of the Dharma.
That giving of material things gives rise to the heavenly fruits of retribution, but one is unable to give.
This person is superior to the gods, and the gods are not superior to humans.
Thus, a human body is extremely difficult to obtain. If one obtains a human body but does not practice giving, it is a wasted life.

It is like a merchant who encounters a treasure island but does not know to take the treasures and returns empty-handed. If one obtains a human body but does not know to give away wealth, it is the same.
What is giving of fearlessness?
How many kinds of giving of fearlessness are there?
Giving of fearlessness is generally of three kinds:
First, saving lives and giving fearlessness;
Second, using skillful means to rescue and protect those whose wives and children are held by others, giving them fearlessness;
Third, protecting those who fear losing their possessions, giving them fearlessness.
The one who saved their life will be reborn among humans and gods, and in return will attain a long life.
The one who protected lost objects will be reborn greatly wealthy, and their possessions will not be taken away or destroyed by kings, thieves, water, or fire;
if they become a king or a great minister, due to that karma they will have great power and great fame, and wherever they are born they will always be greatly wealthy.
The one who saved their wife and children, if reborn among humans, will skillfully care for their wife and children;
when they fall from the heavens, the heavenly maidens will not abandon them.
These are the three kinds of fearless giving.
What is the giving of Dharma?
The giving of Dharma is of two kinds:
one is using worldly dharmas to give;
two is using supramundane dharmas to give.
As for using worldly dharmas to give, it refers to using the four dhyÄnas and worldly wisdom to give.
In the human and heavenly realms one receives worldly happiness, and if reborn among gods and humans, one will give rise to wrong views.
As for giving worldly dharmas, because of non-anger, one is reborn among humans and gods, either in the desire realm or the form realm.
If reborn in the desire realm, one is born on one of the one hundred and ninety-eight grounds, born there according to one's vow.
If reborn in the form realm, one attains liberation, because the fruit is superior, one has great wisdom, and the basis is superior, one attains liberation and is born in the Pure Abodes.
If by the power of vows one becomes a wheel-turning king, ruling the four continents, possessing the golden wheel treasure.
The treasure has fourteen, namely the seven treasures and the seven similar treasures.
By the power of good vows, one exhausts all defilements and attains the path of a pratyekabuddha.

Because of the superiority of vows, one becomes a TathÄgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, one endowed with knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed one, a trainer of those to be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a BhagavÄn.
Because the cause of giving the Dharma is superior.
These three kinds of giving, you heavenly beings, all lack.
For this reason, humans are superior.
Heaven is the ground of retribution, humans are the ground of karma, the ground of causes and conditions.
Thus, in the human realm, heaven arises from causes and conditions, and the fruits of karma are superior.
